body: ONE of the biggest disappointments for New York City's fledgling recycling program has been the low participation by residents in poorer, densely populated neighborhoods. In areas like Harlem or Bedford-Stuyvesant, already overwhelmed by life and death issues, recycling seems trivial. "They're not talking about landfills," said Eddie O'Jay, a
title: The Region; The Poor Mainly Recycle Poverty

body: A third teen-ager was arrested yesterday and charged with being part of a gang that investigators believe held up at least 75 people at gunpoint in Queens and Nassau County in the last two weeks, the police said. Two other suspects were captured on Wednesday night after a wild chase and shootout on the Belt Parkway. Investigators said last night
title: 3 Youths Seized In 75 Robberies In Last 2 Weeks

body: Ten officers in the elite Tactical Narcotics Team are under investigation after allegations were made that they mistreated prisoners and lied about evidence to shore up shaky arrests and justify illegal searches, high-ranking police officials said yesterday. A lieutenant, three sergeants and six police officers from the Brooklyn North Tactical
title: 10 Detectives Face an Inquiry On False Data

body: Yesterday was gray, an ambiguous year is fading and it seemed right to reflect. One remembered O. Henry saying life is smiles, sobs and sniffles -- but mostly sniffles. title: About New York; The Moral Is, The Stories Here Are but Chapters

body: When the feeling hit, Marin Alsop would call up Leonard Bernstein to chat about what Beethoven might have been thinking when he wrote a particular piece of music. title: About New York; Still Learning From the Music And the Master

body: After serving the minimum three and a half years of his sentence for robbery and assault, Michael Williams is scheduled to be released from a Staten Island prison one week from today, on Christmas Eve. title: Metro Matters; Out of Prison And Off of Drugs: This Way Works

body: A 7-year-old girl was killed last night in a fire in her mother's apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said. title: A 7-Year-Old Girl Is Killed In a Bedford-Stuyvesant Fire

body: An 8-year-old Brooklyn boy saved the life of his mother, who is diabetic, last night when he ran four blocks to a police station for help, the police said. The boy, William Dantzler, of 872 Madison Street in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, sought help after his mother, Betty Powell, went into severe insulin shock about 8:30 P.M., said Sgt. Mary
title: 8-Year-Old Boy Runs for Aid, Saving Life of Ailing Mother

body: Two teen-age boys were killed in separate shootings while coming home from parties in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, the police said. In one of the shootings, a gunman killed a 17-year-old boy after stealing his new leather jacket. In the other, the police said, a 14-year-old boy who was found with a large-caliber revolver was fatally shot in
title: TWO TEEN-AGERS SLAIN IN BROOKLYN

body: The Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps officially began on Feb. 23, 1989. Within 24 hours, its president, James Robinson, and a colleague spotted a fire in an abandoned building and saved 10 people. Within 48 hours, volunteers had delivered a baby. The pace never slackened. Drug-related violence devastates this poor Brooklyn neighborhood.
title: About New York; Bed-Stuy, Do or Die. For Real. 911.

body: It is the type of story that movies are based on. A divorced man is frustrated in his efforts to raise his four daughters. title: Neediest Cases Fund Helps a Divorced Father

body: Earl Dicks remembers the day back in 1964 when he and several co-workers at a Harlem building-supply company scraped up what money they could and bought shares in a new bank opening on 125th Street. Civil rights fervor was coursing through the nation, and Freedom National Bank promised to do what establishment banks had not: to finance the economic
title: Failed Dreams - The Collapse of a Harlem Bank; Freedom Bank's Demise: A Trail Of Risky Loans and Fast Growth

body: Rebecca Jones is fighting a war on two fronts: struggling to protect her 12 children from the drugs and violence that overrun her Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood while battling personal demons that made her drink. title: A Tradition of Generosity: Remember the Neediest Cases Fund; Brooklyn Bureau Offers Help to Families

title: 'More Brooms, More Bags, More People' vs. Litter

title: About New York; Global Company Recalls Its Roots In Old Brooklyn

title: Retired Nurse Is Bludgeoned to Death in Brooklyn

body: On a day off for the Jets yesterday, their cornerback James Hasty was busy going to school. In the morning, he visited the St. John Vianney grade school in the Bronx to present a check for $16,000 to establish a scholarship in memory of Jessica Guzman, a 10-year-old honor student who was found slain several weeks ago off the Bronx River Parkway.

title: Guns Offer New York Teen-Agers A Commonplace, Deadly Allure

body: Poor women in New York City are dying of breast cancer unnecessarily, primarily because early detection is not widely practiced in the municipal hospital system, according to a report released yesterday by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. title: Needless Breast Cancer Deaths Reported Among New York's Poor

body: A tie is a pain around the neck. Neckties -- the flashy strips of silk that give the business to "business attire" -- are an affront to the trend toward ease and wantonness. I hate 'em. title: ESSAY; The Ties That Bind
